page.title: 02RIVER ORWELL
page.content: The River Orwell flows from Ipswich to the North Sea at Felixstowe and Harwich. It is used by commercial ships bringing cargoes to and from Ipswich Docks. The channel was dredged in World War II. Until then lighters went out to big ships, anchored below Pin Mill, to take off some of the cargo so that the ships could rise and be able to sail up to Ipswich. The river on each side of the channel is now used for yacht moorings. In the summer the River is full of yachts and sailing dinghies. There is still a little commercial fishing in the river. The mud and saltings on the river banks provide winter feeding grounds for a wide variety of migrant and wading birds. There is a little wild-fowling. The woods that are on both shores make the Orwell a very attractive river.
